key_points: Facebook suspends former President Donald Trump for two years due to severe policy violations following the Capitol riots.
The suspension is set to end in time for the 2024 election cycle, allowing Trump potential social media influence.
Trump's accounts were initially frozen for his support of the Capitol storming, with a potential for permanent removal if violations recur.
Facebook's vice president of global affairs and communications, Nick Clegg, emphasized the sanctions are aimed at preventing future violations.
The Biden White House, through press secretary Jennifer Psaki, hinted skepticism about any change in Trump’s behavior.
Facebook's decision impacts Trump’s fundraising efforts, limiting his ability to support 2022 Republican candidates.
Facebook modifies its policy, stating political figures will not receive special treatment and may face suspension for inciting violence.
Critics from both sides of the political spectrum express discontent with Facebook's decision for different reasons.
Facebook’s Oversight Board influenced the decision-making process but did not directly dictate the two-year suspension.
Future reinstatements will depend on assessments of public safety risks.
spokespersons: Nick Clegg (Vice President of Global Affairs and Communications, Facebook)
